title: Authors and Citation
text: Shipley G (2024). strs: 'Python' Style String Functions. R package version 0.1.1,  https://pythonicr.github.io/strs/, https://github.com/pythonicr/strs.
code: @Manual{,   title = {strs: 'Python' Style String Functions},   author = {Garrett Shipley},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.1,  https://pythonicr.github.io/strs/},   url = {https://github.com/pythonicr/strs}, }

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs R package provides comprehensive set string manipulation functions, mirroring functionality naming conventions Python’s str methods. aims make string operations R accessible users familiar Python. hood, every function uses stringi package ensure results consistent.

title: Python Style String Functions
text: can install strs package directly GitHub.
code: # Install devtools if you haven't already install.packages("devtools")  # Install strs package from GitHub devtools::install_github("pythonicr/strs")

title: Python Style String Functions
text: examples demonstrating use functions provided strs package.

what: Capitalize the First Character of Each Sentence
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_capitalize function capitalizes first character string character vector.
code: library(strs)  # Capitalize the first character of each sentence capitalized <- strs_capitalize("hello world") print(capitalized) #> [1] "Hello world"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_casefold function performs case folding element character vector, useful case-insensitive matching.
code: # Perform case folding folded <- strs_casefold("HELLO World") print(folded) #> [1] "hello world"

what: Center a String in a Field of a Given Width
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_center function centers element character vector field specified width, padding specified character.
code: # Center a string with padding centered <- strs_center("hello", 10) print(centered) #> [1] "  hello   "

what: Check if String Contains a Substring
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_contains function checks whether element character vector contains specified substring.
code: # Check if strings contain a substring contains <- strs_contains("hello world", "world") print(contains) #> [1] TRUE

what: Count Occurrences of a Substring in a String
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_count function counts number times specified substring occurs element character vector.
code: # Count occurrences of a substring count <- strs_count("hello world", "o") print(count) #> [1] 2

what: Check if String Ends With a Specified Suffix
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_endswith function determines whether element character vector ends specified suffix.
code: # Check if strings end with a suffix endswith <- strs_endswith("hello world", "world") print(endswith) #> [1] TRUE

what: Expand Tabs in a String to Spaces
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_expandtabs function replaces tab character (\t) string specified number spaces.
code: # Expand tabs to spaces expanded <- strs_expandtabs("hello\tworld", 4) print(expanded) #> [1] "hello    world"

what: Find the First Occurrence of a Substring in a String
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_find function locates first occurrence specified substring within element character vector.
code: # Find the first occurrence of a substring first_occurrence <- strs_find("hello world", "world") print(first_occurrence) #> [1] 7

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_isalnum function checks whether element character vector alphanumeric.
code: # Check if strings are alphanumeric isalnum <- strs_isalnum("hello123") print(isalnum) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check if String Contains Only Alphabetical Characters
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_isalpha function checks whether element character vector contains alphabetical characters.
code: # Check if strings are alphabetical isalpha <- strs_isalpha("hello") print(isalpha) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check if String Contains Only ASCII Characters
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_isascii function determines whether element character vector contains ASCII characters.
code: # Check if strings are ASCII isascii <- strs_isascii("hello") print(isascii) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check if String Contains Only Decimal Characters
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_isdecimal function checks whether element character vector contains decimal characters.
code: # Check if strings are decimal isdecimal <- strs_isdecimal("12345") print(isdecimal) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check if String Contains Only Digits
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_isdigit function checks whether element character vector contains digits.
code: # Check if strings are digits isdigit <- strs_isdigit("12345") print(isdigit) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check if String is in Lowercase
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_islower function checks whether element character vector lowercase.
code: # Check if strings are lowercase islower <- strs_islower("hello") print(islower) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check if String Contains Only Numeric Characters
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_isnumeric function checks whether element character vector contains numeric characters.
code: # Check if strings are numeric isnumeric <- strs_isnumeric("12345") print(isnumeric) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check if String Contains Only Whitespace Characters
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_isspace function checks whether element character vector contains whitespace characters.
code: # Check if strings are whitespace isspace <- strs_isspace("    ") print(isspace) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check if String is in Title Case
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_istitle function checks whether element character vector title case.
code: # Check if strings are title case istitle <- strs_istitle("This Is Title Case") print(istitle) #> [1] TRUE

what: Check if String is in Uppercase
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_isupper function checks whether element character vector uppercase.
code: # Check if strings are uppercase isupper <- strs_isupper("HELLO") print(isupper) #> [1] TRUE

what: Join Elements into a Single String with a Separator
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_join function concatenates elements iterable using separator.
code: # Join elements with a separator joined <- strs_join("-", c("hello", "world")) print(joined) #> [1] "hello-world"

what: Left-justify String in a Field of a Given Width
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_ljust function left-justifies element character vector field specified width.
code: # Left-justify a string ljust <- strs_ljust("hello", 10) print(ljust) #> [1] "     hello"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_lower function converts element character vector lowercase, based specified locale.
code: # Convert strings to lowercase lower <- strs_lower("HELLO WORLD") print(lower) #> [1] "hello world"

what: Left Strip Characters from a String
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_lstrip function removes leading characters (spaces default) element character vector.
code: # Left-strip characters lstrip <- strs_lstrip("    hello world") print(lstrip) #> [1] "hello world"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_normalize_whitespace function normalizes whitespace element character vector.
code: # Normalize whitespace normalized <- strs_normalize_whitespace("  hello   world  ") print(normalized) #> [1] "hello world"

what: Remove a Prefix from a String
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_removeprefix function removes specified prefix start element character vector.
code: # Remove a prefix removed_prefix <- strs_removeprefix("testString", "test") print(removed_prefix) #> [1] "String"

what: Remove a Suffix from a String
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_removesuffix function removes specified suffix end element character vector.
code: # Remove a suffix removed_suffix <- strs_removesuffix("StringTest", "Test") print(removed_suffix) #> [1] "String"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_replace function replaces occurrences specified substring element character vector.
code: # Replace a substring replaced <- strs_replace("hello world", "world", "there") print(replaced) #> [1] "hello there"

what: Find the Last Occurrence of a Substring in a String
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_rfind function locates last occurrence specified substring within element character vector.
code: # Find the last occurrence of a substring last_occurrence <- strs_rfind("hello world", "o") print(last_occurrence) #> [1] 8   # 8

what: Right-justify String in a Field of a Given Width
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_rjust function right-justifies element character vector field specified width.
code: # Right-justify a string rjust <- strs_rjust("hello", 10) print(rjust) #> [1] "hello     "

what: Right Strip Characters from a String
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_rstrip function removes trailing characters (spaces default) element character vector.
code: # Right-strip characters rstrip <- strs_rstrip("hello world    ") print(rstrip) #> [1] "hello world"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_slice function extracts substrings element character vector, specified start stop positions.
code: # Slice substrings sliced <- strs_slice("hello world", 1, 5) print(sliced) #> [1] "hello"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_split function splits element character vector substrings based separator.
code: # Split strings into substrings split <- strs_split("hello world", " ") print(split)  # list("hello", "world") #> [[1]] #> [1] "hello" "world"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_splitlines function splits element character vector separate lines.
code: # Split strings into lines split_lines <- strs_splitlines("hello\nworld\n") print(split_lines)  # list("hello", "world") #> [[1]] #> [1] "hello" "world"

what: Check if String Starts With a Specified Prefix
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_startswith function determines whether element character vector starts specified prefix.
code: # Check if strings start with a prefix startswith <- strs_startswith("hello world", "hello") print(startswith) #> [1] TRUE

what: Strip Characters from Both Ends of a String
title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_strip function removes leading trailing characters (spaces default) element character vector.
code: # Strip characters from both ends strip <- strs_strip("    hello world    ") print(strip) #> [1] "hello world"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_title function converts element character vector title case, based specified locale.
code: # Convert strings to title case title <- strs_title("hello world") print(title) #> [1] "Hello World"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: strs_upper function converts element character vector uppercase, based specified locale.
code: # Convert strings to uppercase upper <- strs_upper("hello world") print(upper) #> [1] "HELLO WORLD"

title: Python Style String Functions
text: welcome contributions strs package. suggestions, bug reports, want contribute code, please open issue submit pull request GitHub repository. capitalize casefold center count encode endswith expandtabs find format format_map index isalnum isalpha isascii isdecimal isdigit isidentifier islower isnumeric isprintable isspace istitle isupper join ljust lower lstrip maketrans partition removeprefix removesuffix replace rfind rindex rjust rpartition rsplit rstrip split splitlines startswith strip swapcase title translate upper zfill

title: Python Style String Functions

what: Capitalize the first character of each sentence — strs_capitalize
title: Capitalize the first character of each sentence — strs_capitalize
text: function capitalizes first character string given string, based specified locale. similar Python's str.capitalize() method.

title: Capitalize the first character of each sentence — strs_capitalize
Capitalize the first character of each sentence — strs_capitalize
text: string character vector element string capitalized. locale character string representing locale used capitalization. Defaults "en" (English). locale affects rules identifying sentences string.

title: Capitalize the first character of each sentence — strs_capitalize
text: character vector length string, element capitalized version corresponding element string.

title: Capitalize the first character of each sentence — strs_capitalize

what: Perform case folding on strings — strs_casefold
title: Perform case folding on strings — strs_casefold
text: strs_casefold used perform case folding element character vector. function particularly useful case-insensitive string matching similar Python's str.casefold() method.

title: Perform case folding on strings — strs_casefold
Perform case folding on strings — strs_casefold
text: string character vector element string case-folded.

title: Perform case folding on strings — strs_casefold
text: character vector length string, element case-folded.

title: Perform case folding on strings — strs_casefold

what: Center a string in a field of a given width — strs_center
title: Center a string in a field of a given width — strs_center
text: strs_center centers element character vector field specified width. pads string sides specified character (defaulting space). similar Python's str.center() method.

title: Center a string in a field of a given width — strs_center
Center a string in a field of a given width — strs_center
text: string character vector element string centered. width total width field string centered. fillchar character used padding. specified, defaults space. first character fillchar used longer one character.

title: Center a string in a field of a given width — strs_center
text: character vector length string, element centered field specified width.

title: Center a string in a field of a given width — strs_center

what: Check if string contains a substring — strs_contains
title: Check if string contains a substring — strs_contains
text: strs_contains checks whether element character vector contains specified substring. function mirrors functionality Python's str.__contains__() method.

title: Check if string contains a substring — strs_contains
Check if string contains a substring — strs_contains
text: string character vector element string checked. substring substring search within element string.

title: Check if string contains a substring — strs_contains
text: logical vector length string, element indicating whether corresponding element string contains substring.

title: Check if string contains a substring — strs_contains
code: strs_contains("hello world", "world") #> [1] TRUE strs_contains(c("apple", "banana", "cherry"), "a") #> [1]  TRUE  TRUE FALSE

what: Count occurrences of a substring in a string — strs_count
title: Count occurrences of a substring in a string — strs_count
text: strs_count counts number times specified substring occurs element character vector. Optionally, search can limited substring element, specified start end positions. function similar Python's str.count() method.

title: Count occurrences of a substring in a string — strs_count
Count occurrences of a substring in a string — strs_count
text: string character vector element string count occurrences substring. substring substring count within element string. start optional integer specifying starting position element string search. Defaults 1, indicating start string. end optional integer specifying ending position element string search. default value -1 indicates end string.

title: Count occurrences of a substring in a string — strs_count
text: integer vector length string, element indicating count substring corresponding element string.

title: Count occurrences of a substring in a string — strs_count
code: strs_count("hello world", "o") #> [1] 2 strs_count("banana", "na") #> [1] 2 strs_count("hello world", "o", start = 6) #> [1] 1 strs_count("hello world", "o", end = 5) #> [1] 1

what: Check if string ends with a specified suffix — strs_endswith
title: Check if string ends with a specified suffix — strs_endswith
text: strs_endswith determines whether element character vector ends specified suffix. function similar Python's str.endswith() method.

title: Check if string ends with a specified suffix — strs_endswith
Check if string ends with a specified suffix — strs_endswith
text: string character vector element string checked. suffix suffix check end element string.

title: Check if string ends with a specified suffix — strs_endswith
text: logical vector length string, element indicating whether corresponding element string ends suffix.

title: Check if string ends with a specified suffix — strs_endswith
code: strs_endswith("hello world", "world") #> [1] TRUE strs_endswith(c("test", "hello", "world"), "ld") #> [1] FALSE FALSE  TRUE

what: Expand tabs in a string to spaces — strs_expandtabs
title: Expand tabs in a string to spaces — strs_expandtabs
text: strs_expandtabs replaces tab character (\\t) string specified number spaces. function behaves similarly Python's str.expandtabs() method.

title: Expand tabs in a string to spaces — strs_expandtabs
Expand tabs in a string to spaces — strs_expandtabs
text: string character vector element string expand tabs. tabsize integer specifying number spaces replace tab character . Defaults 8.

title: Expand tabs in a string to spaces — strs_expandtabs
text: character vector length string, tabs element replaced tabsize number spaces.

title: Expand tabs in a string to spaces — strs_expandtabs

what: Inline String Interpolation with Environment Variables — strs_f
title: Inline String Interpolation with Environment Variables — strs_f
text: strs_f function allows inline variable interpolation strings, similar Python's f-strings.

title: Inline String Interpolation with Environment Variables — strs_f
Inline String Interpolation with Environment Variables — strs_f
text: string character vector containing string placeholders curly braces {}. vector contains one string, concatenated interpolation.

title: Inline String Interpolation with Environment Variables — strs_f
text: character vector placeholders replaced evaluated expressions.

title: Inline String Interpolation with Environment Variables — strs_f
text: hood, function uses glue::glue() function perform interpolation. However, function let change evaluation context perform string trimming. interpolated expression NA, NA output. interpolated expression NULL, NULL output.

title: Inline String Interpolation with Environment Variables — strs_f
code: name <- "Alice" age <- 30 strs_f("My name is {name} and I am {age} years old.") #> Error: Failed to evaluate glue component {name} #> Caused by error: #> ! object 'name' not found # Output: "My name is Alice and I am 30 years old." age <- NULL strs_f("My name is {name} and I am {age} years old.") #> Error: Failed to evaluate glue component {name} #> Caused by error: #> ! object 'name' not found # Output: "My name is Alice and I am NULL years old."

what: Find the first occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_find
title: Find the first occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_find
text: strs_find locates first occurrence specified substring within element character vector. function analogous Python's str.find() method.

title: Find the first occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_find
Find the first occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_find
text: string character vector element string search. substring substring find within element string.

title: Find the first occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_find
text: integer vector length string, element representing starting position first occurrence substring corresponding element string. substring found, function returns NA element.

title: Find the first occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_find

what: String Interpolation with Data Support — strs_format
title: String Interpolation with Data Support — strs_format
text: strs_format function provides string interpolation using values data argument, similar Python's str.format method. information, see details.

title: String Interpolation with Data Support — strs_format
String Interpolation with Data Support — strs_format
text: string character vector containing string placeholders curly braces {}. vector contains one string, concatenated interpolation.

title: String Interpolation with Data Support — strs_format
text: character vector placeholders replaced evaluated expressions.

title: String Interpolation with Data Support — strs_format
text: hood, function uses glue::glue_data() function perform interpolation. default, function use variables provided ... .data. use immediate environment perform interpolations. interpolated expression NA, NA output. interpolated expression NULL, NULL output.

title: String Interpolation with Data Support — strs_format
code: # Using a named list for substitutions data_list <- list(name = "Alice", age = 30) strs_format("My name is {name} and I am {age} years old.", .data = data_list) #> My name is Alice and I am 30 years old. # Output: "My name is Alice and I am 30 years old."  # Using additional arguments strs_format("My name is {name} and I am {age} years old.", name = "Bob", age = 25) #> My name is Bob and I am 25 years old. # Output: "My name is Bob and I am 25 years old."

text: strs_lstrip removes leading characters (spaces default) element character vector. similar Python's str.lstrip() method.

title: Left strip characters from a string — strs_lstrip
Left strip characters from a string — strs_lstrip
text: string character vector element string left-stripped. chars optional string characters removed beginning element. NULL, whitespace removed.

title: Left strip characters from a string — strs_lstrip
text: character vector length string, specified characters removed beginning element.

title: Left strip characters from a string — strs_lstrip
code: strs_lstrip("    hello world") #> [1] "hello world" strs_lstrip("xxxyhello world", chars = "xy") #> [1] "hello world"

text: strs_normalize_whitespace normalizes whitespace element character vector. trims leading trailing whitespace replaces sequence whitespace characters within string single space. function akin typical Python pattern " ".join(str.split()).

text: string character vector element string normalize whitespace.

text: character vector length string, whitespace normalized element.

what: Find the last occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_rfind
title: Find the last occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_rfind

text: string character vector element string search. substring substring find within element string.

title: Find the last occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_rfind
text: integer vector length string, element representing starting position last occurrence substring corresponding element string. substring found, function returns NA element.

title: Find the last occurrence of a substring in a string — strs_rfind
code: strs_rfind("hello world", "o") #> [1] 8 strs_rfind("hello world", "x") # not found #> [1] NA

what: Slice substrings from a string — strs_slice
title: Slice substrings from a string — strs_slice
text: strs_slice extracts substrings element character vector, specified start stop positions. similar Python's slicing syntax strings, uses 1 indexing stops inclusive.

title: Slice substrings from a string — strs_slice
Slice substrings from a string — strs_slice
text: string character vector element string slice. start integerish scalar starting position slicing (inclusive). stop integerish scalar ending position slicing (inclusive). ... Used force keyword argument usage step. step integer greater 0 equal -1 step size. -1 provided, string reversed slicing operations.

title: Slice substrings from a string — strs_slice
text: character vector length string, element sliced substring.

title: Slice substrings from a string — strs_slice
code: strs_slice("hello world", 1, 5) #> [1] "hello" strs_slice("hello world", 7) #> [1] "world" strs_slice("hello world", start = 7, stop = 11) #> [1] "world"

what: Check if string starts with a specified prefix — strs_startswith

text: string character vector element string checked. prefix prefix check start element string.

title: Check if string starts with a specified prefix — strs_startswith
text: logical vector length string, element indicating whether corresponding element string starts prefix.

title: Check if string starts with a specified prefix — strs_startswith
code: strs_startswith("hello world", "hello") #> [1] TRUE strs_startswith(c("test", "hello", "world"), "te") #> [1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE

code: strs_title("hello world") #> [1] "Hello World" strs_title("guten tag", locale = "de") #> [1] "Guten Tag"
